p: The WHO estimates that about one-third of the world’s population has latent TB. These people have the TB bacteria, but are not ill, and do not infect others. On average the lifetime risk of an infected person falling ill with TB is around 10%, however this number is significantly higher for certain groups. HIV+ people are over 26% more likely to develop TB (WHO 2014d). Children and people in low- and lower-middle income countries face a heightened risk of falling ill. Africa has the greatest proportion of new TB cases with 280 falling ill per 100,000 in 2013. In North America, the rate is only 3–4 people per 100,000 annually (WHO 2014d; World Bank 2015).
